description: A five-building cycle tour looking at housing, leisure, mixed-use and later living architecture in Waltham Forest designed by Pollard Thomas Edwards (PTE). It starts at Lea Bridge Road Station and ends at Waltham Forest Town Hall and will be led by Justin Laskin, partner, who designed several of the schemes and Rory Olcayto, PTE’s writer and critic and the former chief executive of Open House.

events.name: Waltham Forest cycle tour
events.notes: A five-building cycle tour looking at housing, leisure, mixed-use and later living architecture in Waltham Forest designed by PTE.

factsheet.heading: Motion
paragraphs: Three stylish towers and a new landscaped square complement the re-opening of Lea Bridge station and signal a new identity for this major regeneration area. Replacing dilapidated warehouses, the development ranges from 4 to 18 storeys and delivers 300 homes and around 1,500 sqm of commercial and leisure space.

factsheet.heading: South Grove
paragraphs: A new urban quarter with over 500 homes is emerging near Walthamstow town centre, featuring a street network, public square and linear park. Detached mansion blocks line the railway boundary and provide every home with an outlook towards quiet gardens.

factsheet.heading: Juniper House
paragraphs: Sixteen-storey Juniper House features 91 new mixed-tenure homes - more than half affordable - alongside a nursery for 53 local children. The mixed-use development, designed by PTE and built by Hill, is located on a brownfield site opposite Walthamstow Central, one of London’s busiest local stations. Juniper House also contains two floors of classrooms, a winter garden and social space for the University of Portsmouth’s London campus as well as street-level commercial units and a new ‘pocket park’ connecting adjacent residential streets.

factsheet.heading: The Scene
paragraphs: This sinuous development brings residents back into the town centre and creates a buzzing leisure economy around a multiplex cinema, restaurants and shops. 121 apartments surround a shared roof-garden.

factsheet.heading: Colby Lodge
paragraphs: An evolution of the traditional almshouse, this project retains the virtues of shelter and security while providing social spaces for residents and communal facilities that can be opened up to the community, without compromising residents’ privacy. Generous dual aspect daylighting of all flats combined with high levels of insulation make ideal homes for the Third Age of life, while wide access galleries and accessible gardens have already become popular gathering places.
Colby Lodge embodies the idea that an almshouse can be affordable, inviting and a lively neighbourhood hub when required, as well as a comfortable, secure home.

travel_info:
Additional travel info: Start point: Lea Bridge Road Station
End point: Waltham Forest Town Hall

name: Pollard Thomas Edwards Waltham Forest cycle tour
